chapter.title: Equivalence, Implication, and Laws of Logic

section.title: Reading
section.p: Read sections 3.3 and 3.4 of Applied Discrete Structures.
Response question: Explain why every proposition implies a tautology.

Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:
Construct the truth table for x= (p \land \neg q) \lor (r \land p).
Find an example other than x itself of a proposition generated by p, q, and r that is equivalent to x.
Find an example of a proposition that is not equivalent to x and that implies x.
Find an example of a proposition that is not equivalent to x and that is implied by x.
Show that the common fallacy (p\to q) \land \neg p \Rightarrow \neg q is not a law of logic.

li.p: Find a proposition that is equivalent to p \lor q and uses only conjunction and negation.

Frankie Fib was telling you what he consumed yesterday afternoon. He tells you, I had either popcorn or raisins. Also, if I had cucumber sandwiches, then I had soda. But I didn't drink soda or tea. Of course you know that Frankie is the worlds worst liar, and everything he says is false. What did Frankie have to eat and drink?
Construct the truth table for (p \rightarrow q) \land (q \rightarrow r) \land (r \rightarrow p). Notice anything about the result?

The significance of the Sheffer Stroke is that it is a universal operation in that all other logical operations can be built from it.
Prove that p | q is equivalent to \neg (p \land q).
Prove that \neg p \Leftrightarrow p | p.
Build \land using only the Sheffer Stroke.
Build \lor using only the Sheffer Stroke.

section.title: The Sheffer Stroke
section.p: Another logical operation is the Sheffer Stroke, which is the subject of one of the exercises.
